Openmix Application Development Tool
====================================

**This project is currently in a planning/pre-Alpha stage.**

    :target: https://travis-ci.org/gratopia/opxtool

Openmix is a software-defined DNS load-balancing system, developed and delivered by Cedexis_ [1]_. In a typical scenario, you create a CNAME for your domain to a Cedexis Openmix application CNAME. When a request for your domain hits the application, it is responsible for answering with another CNAME (or a set of one or more A/AAAA records). In this way, the application can route between two or more delivery networks, or other infrastructure resources, often based on near real-time real-user performance data provided by `Cedexis Radar`_.

To create an Openmix application, you can either choose a "quickstart" application in the Cedexis portal, or upload a custom JavaScript application based on the Openmix API [2]_. Quickstart applications perform very well and are sufficient most of time. However, if you have a complex use case and need access to the wide array of options provided by the API, or if you simply prefer to control the software directly, a custom JavaScript application remains a good option.

A trivial Openmix app written in JavaScript can be quite simple.

.. code-block:: javascript

    function onRequest(_, response) {
        response.addARecord('1.2.3.4');
    }

However, real world apps generally do quite a bit more.

Opxtool is a command-line utility used to generate and maintain Openmix applications. It is configuration-driven, meaning that you can avoid writing any JavaScript if you don't want to. Through a configuration file, you can compose an application declaratively. You can also specify a body of input data and expected results in order to test it. *The goal is to allow us to reason about an application's configuration, rather than its implementation in JavaScript.*

Features available for inclusion in Openmix apps generated by the tool are provided by plugins. The tool comes with a set of reference plugins that should satisfy many use cases, but you can install more with ``pip``, or create your own. For more information, see `Plugins`_.

Usage::

    $ opxtool <operation> <arguments>

Operations
----------

This is an overview of some of the basic operations. More information is available by running ``opxtool --help`` or by reading the documentation_.

init
^^^^

Initialize a new application in the specified subdirectory relative to the working directory. The destination subdirectory must *not* already exist.

Example::

    $ opxtool init my-new-application
